bioghist.p: Crawford H. Greenewalt (1902-1993) received his bachelor's degree in chemical engineering from the Massachusetts Institute of Technology in 1922. He began his career as a chemist and worked in four manufacturing and two auxiliary departments of E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. and later served as a vice president, a director and president from 1948 to 1962. He served as board chairman from 1962 to 1967. He played a major role in the development of nylon and in 1941 was assigned to the Manhattan Project to act as a liaison between University of Chicago physicists and DuPont engineering and construction crews. His widely varied interests included birds and high-speed photography; he combined those interests in the book Hummingbirds, published in 1960. In 1968 he published another book on the subject, Bird Song: Acoustics and Physiology.

scopecontent.p: This collection documents Greenewalt's work as a photographer of birds and an ornithologist. Materials in the collection include: black and white and color photographic prints, negatives, film and glass slides, transparencies, stereo photographs, and movies of hummingbirds, songbirds, and other bird families; field notebooks (1956-1983), which document the location, equipment, and lighting used for Greenewalt's bird photography; manuscripts and reprints of Greenewalt's works on hummingbirds, and motion and sound studies; graphs, charts, and sound wave printouts related to Greenewalt's study of flight and birdsong; notebooks of data from flight tests and observations; photographs and microscope slides of hummingbird feathers; maps and pencil sketches of birds; a typescript of a talk on John Gould and William Baily given by Greenwalt at the American Philosophical Society in 1980, along with a set of slides of Gould and Baily artwork; camera equipment, manufacturers' equipment manuals, and notes on results of equipment tests performed by Greenewalt; documents related to the Academy's VIREO project include technical and equipment manuals, descriptions of the program, and correspondence between Greenewalt and Academy staff. The collection also includes some personal items including awards, certificates, honorary degrees, slides of family and friends.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
